Award.AwardTitle: EAGER/Cybermanufacturing: Cyber-Enabled Additive Manufacturing of Advanced Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Additive manufacturing (AM), a process of printing a 3-dimensional solid object from a digital model, makes it possible to produce virtually any geometric complexity with very little impact on cost. However, most of the current AM technologies have not yet begun to achieve their full potential. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will explore the feasibility of advancing AM technologies, focusing on capacities that differ from conventional manufacturing processes, such as the ability to create materials with properties not generally observed in nature. These capabilities will lead to breakthrough manufacturing technologies, such as structural amorphous metals with much stronger and lighter products that cannot be currently made, and repairing parts stronger than their original condition. Thus the project will provide a transformative method to fabricate advanced materials. The strength, hardness, and fatigue properties of fabricated materials will also enable extremely lightweight structure design, thus revolutionize many products in the market. Therefore, results from this research will benefit the U.S. manufacturing industry.

This project will demonstrate the feasibility of a novel Cyber-enabled Additive Manufacturing (CyberAM) system to transform material fabrication capability. Using the CyberAM system, structural amorphous metals will be fabricated using a metal AM system through well-controlled high cooling process. This project will also advance the knowledge of cybermanufacturing, including 1) a methodology to effectively extract process model information into a unified CyberAM representation for real time process monitoring and control; 2) a strategy to simplify model computation and data generation to support cyber manufacturing; 3) a learning and adaptation architecture to continuously improve process model and database using sensor feedback; and 4) CyberAM demonstration with the learned knowledge to make novel materials. If successful, the researchers will be able to extend the developed knowledge to internet scale to support multiple AM stations to fabricate advanced materials that cannot be made before.

Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

Performance_Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
EAGER: Cybermanufacturing: Cyber-Enabled Additive Manufacturing of Advanced Materials

The EAGER project was to explore the feasibility of advancing additive manufacturing (AM) technologies, focusing on capacities that differ from conventional manufacturing processes, such as the anisotropic nature of AM, the description and manufacture of functionally gradient materials and multiple materials, and the ability to create materials with properties not generally observed in nature. These capabilities will lead to breakthrough manufacturing technologies, such as producing much stronger and lighter products that cannot currently be made, and repairing parts stronger than their original condition. The objective of this proposed project is to explore the feasibility of a novel cyber-enabled Additive Manufacturing (CyberAM) for advanced material fabrication capability, and to advance the knowledge of Cybermanufacturing. We also integrated the research with education and training.

This project has demonstrated the feasibility of a novel CyberAM system to transform novel material fabrication capability. Effective methodologies have been developed to extract process model information. Novel model computation and data generation have been developed. To demonstrate the concept, an in-situ cooling system that works in line with the laser deposition system to extract the excess heat buildup and reduce the variation in the hardness of the Ni-based clad alloy deposit across its height, has been developed.  This experimental setup has been integrated with process modeling. Comparative micro-hardness tests have been performed on deposits made with the new system and without. The results indicate a significant reduction in the variation of the micro-hardness across the deposit along with an enhancement in the mean hardness value of the clad material. This shows the feasibility of CyberAM system to effectively control the microstructure the AM parts.  

This research has demonstrated the feasibility of a cyber-enabled AM system that can be used to effectively create new classes of patentable materials, including Functionally Gradient Materials (FGMs), and other high-performance materials that require consistent and reliable microstructures. It has provided a transformative method to fabricate advanced materials.  The strength, hardness, and fatigue properties of the deposition will enable extremely lightweight structure design, thus revolutionize many products in the market.  FGMs will allow unlimited combinations of materials for future products.  By having the ability to deliver on-demand material properties, this CyberAM system can potentially cater to the high precision needs of many sectors including aerospace, medical manufacturing, optics and underwater navigation, etc.  This platform by nature requires interdisciplinary knowledge in the areas of empirical modelling, thermodynamics, machine learning and control, materials characterization will act as an excellent training medium for the engineers of tomorrow.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2018
Modified by: Frank Liou
